contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox political party | party_name = Social Liberal Party | native_name = ''{{lang|ar|الحزب الاجتماعي التحرري}} | lang1 = French | name_lang1 = Parti social-libéral | colorcode = {{Social Liberal Party (Tunisia)/meta/color}} | chairman = [[Mondher Thabet]] | foundation = {{Start date|1988|09|12}} | headquarters = {{nowrap|42 avenue Hédi Chaker}} <br> 1002 [[Tunis]] | ideology = [[Liberalism]] | international = [[Liberal International]] | affiliation1_title = African affiliation | affiliation1 = [[Africa Liberal Network]] | seats1_title = [[Tunisian Constituent Assembly election, 2011|Constituent Assembly]] | seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|0|217|hex={{Social Liberal Party (Tunisia)/meta/color}}}} | colours = [[Orange (colour)|Orange]] | website = [http://psltunisie.maktoobblog.com/] | country = Tunisia }} The '''Social Liberal Party''' ({{lang-ar|الحزب الاجتماعي التحرري}} ; {{lang-fr|Parti social-libéral}}), abbreviated to '''PSL''', is an [[opposition (political)|opposition]] [[liberalism|liberal]] [[political party]] in [[Tunisia]]. The party is a member of the [[Liberal International]]<ref>[http://www.liberal-international.org/editorial.asp?ia_id=1654 File on the LI site]</ref> and the [[Africa Liberal Network]]. The party was founded in September 1988 under the name "Social Party for Progress" ({{lang-fr|Parti social pour le progrès}}), but was renamed in October 1993 to reflect its liberal ideology.<ref>{{cite book |title=Europa World Year Book 2, Book 2 |editor-last=Maher |editor-first=Joanne |year=2004 |publisher=Europa Publications |location=London |isbn=978-1-85743-255-8 |page=4201 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C |accessdate=}}</ref> At the [[Tunisian general election, 1999|1999 election]], it won election for the first time, winning its first two seats in the Chamber of Deputies. They retained these two seats at the [[Tunisian general election, 2004|2004]], when its candidate [[Mohamed Mouni Béji]] also won 0.8% at the [[President of Tunisia|presidential]] elections. In 2005, [[Mongi Khamassi]], one of the party's founders, split to form the [[Green Party for Progress]]. Despite this, the PSL quadrupled its seats to eight in the [[Tunisian general election, 2009|2009 election]], making it the fifth-largest party. As well as liberal social and political reforms, the PSL advocates [[economic liberalisation]], including the [[privatisation]] of state-owned firms.<ref>{{cite book |title=Political Handbook of the World 2008 |editor1-last=Banks |editor1-first=Arthur S. |editor2-last=Muller |editor2-first=Thomas C. |editor3-last=Overstreet |editor3-first=William |year=2004 |publisher=Europa Publications |location=London |isbn=978-1-85743-255-8 |page=1345 |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gP_-8rXzQs8C |accessdate=}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Liberalism]] *[[Social liberalism]] *[[Contributions to liberal theory]] *[[Liberalism worldwide]] *[[List of liberal parties]] *[[Liberal democracy]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://psltunisie.maktoobblog.com/ Social Liberal Party] official site {{Tunisian political parties}} {{interlib}} {{liberalparty-stub}} {{Tunisia-party-stub}} [[Category:Liberal parties in Tunisia]] [[Category:Social liberal parties]]
